fields.summary: provide visual warning when VPC security groups associated with ELBs don't have necessary listener ports open

fields.summary: VPC ELB fails to add a listener when there are too many listeners with different ports

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description:
EUCA-12469 describes a change to the way an ELB adds listeners. In a VPC setup, it currently enables the port for the listener on the VPC security group being used by the ELB. That VPC is also owned by the user, so automatically opening ports on their VPC security group is considered bad practice.
We could take a couple of approaches:
 - alert them that they will need to authorize certain ports manually (and link them to where they can do that)
 - alert them about the needed authorization and let them confirm letting us do that (or cancel if they don't agree).
fields.summary: Authorize ports for ELB created in VPC

comments.body: [~jloza], we need to decide how to handle this in 4.3 and I'm willing to do the work so that we can better understand the code impact if we wanted to get this console change into 4.3. Otherwise 4.3.1 is the next obvious target for the fix.
I think at this point we need to target this to 4.3.1. Thanks!
When testing the linked ticket, I found we're already warning the user.
Needs new dialog text and functionality to open the ports for them.

Balsamiq in Confluence is DOR at the moment, so I am attaching a revised wireframe to this ticket. Notice that dialog title and text have changed, there is a new checkbox, and new code is required to update the group for the user if the box is checked (it's checked by default).
Added to Release Notes 4.3

[~jloza]: An ELB in a VPC can have multiple security groups, so we'll probably need to change the "Update the security group for me" checkbox to something that handles multiple security groups, right?  Should we perhaps embed a drop-down in that sentence (e.g. "Update security group <sgroup single-select chosen widget here> for me")?  Or should we display that checkbox only when a single security group is selected for the ELB?
hi [~kgill], in the dialog text and checkbox, just change "group" to "group(s)" and be sure you stack all the security groups and ports in the lists.

[~spark]: If an ELB in a VPC has multiple security groups, do all groups need to have rules with the ports open for the ELB's listeners, or would it be adequate for one security group to have the necessary rules to open the listener ports?
[~kgill] All security groups need to have the port open.

I would never default to 0.0.0.0/0. When we open the ports, we should let them tell us the CIDR (or security group) to open the ports to. It seems like we need to lift the parts of the rules editor that handle CIDR or group and plop them down here.

Yeah, I am wondering if there are specific CIDRs or security groups that they need to be open to. Hopefully there's a known source or CIDR, or one we can programmatically figure out? I would ask [~spark] for guidance here.
[~jloza] It's up to the user and applications to determine the CIDRs to authorize.
hi [~spark], could you please describe here what changes were made as the fix for the associated EUCA-12469 ticket? What does the back end do?

[~jloza] In classic ELB (non-VPC), all ELBs were supposed to serve traffics from public Internet and AWS/EUCA automatically authorize CIDR for all (0.0.0.0/0). In VPC mode, AWS/EUCA allows users to manage their security groups associated with ELBs so that they can enforce any restriction as necessary. We had a bug that authorizes the ports in VPC mode too and EUCA-12469 is the fix.

Thanks, [~spark]!

I think we need to rework this dialog based on this new info. We probably need to A) be sure for EDGE mode we simply open the ports to all traffic and B) allow the user to specify a CIDR or SG identifier if they want to. I'll update the wireframe.

[~spark], question: would the **most common use cases** for this open all ports on all specified listener security groups to the same traffic (CIDR or security group)? Or all ports for each specified security group (with each security group perhaps using different CIDRs). Or could the most common thing to be to specify different CIDR or security group for each port? Or the same for all inbound and all outbound, but inbound and outbound different from each other?

Hopefully there's some simple option we can present to users that will satisfy the most common config use case? Anything less common they can go do on the individual security groups. Thoughts?

[~jloza] In EDGE mode, console needs to do nothing regarding the security group. ELB automatically does that and in fact console has no API access to the ELB's security group. 

In my opinion, in VPC mode console shouldn't do anything to the security groups that users assign to ELB. It is by design in accordance with the security practice to let users manage and choose the security groups. Because there are multiple listener ports and multiple security groups that can be mixed in an ELB, it is too difficult (or impossible because those security groups are used for other purposes than ELB) for console to safely manage them.

Instead, during the creation of ELB, console can provide a link to security groups landing page to allow users to configure (or create) and pick one or multiple security groups to be used for ELB. After users choose security groups, console should provide warning if there's any red or yellow flag, such as:
  -- for some listener ports, the security group(s) do not authorize the ports (probably red flag)
  -- for some listener ports, the security groups(s) authorize them, but CIDR is not for public (yellow flag?)
  -- the security group(s) have the ports open that is not one of the listener ports (yellow flag? because the group might be used for other applications too).

That's just my thought.

[~jloza] "Some listener ports" means the the listeners that users specify during the creation of ELB. There can be multiple listeners and each listener has a port. Among such ports, there can be "some" that conflicts with the rules in the security groups.

[~jloza]: I wonder if the simplest fix for 4.3.1 is to link each security group in the warning dialog to the group's details page, perhaps opening in a new window to avoid losing context when creating or updating the load balancer?  That way the user has access to the list of ports (in the warning dialog) when modifying their security group(s) and can easily jump back to the ELB wizard (or details page) to finish creating/updating the load balancer.
Closing as won't fix, based on a console team meeting discussion on 8/25/16
